newsitem.title: MEXICO: Pemex's Lajous outlines 1997 budget assumptions. [CORRECTED 00:15 GMT 7/11]
newsitem.headline: Pemex's Lajous outlines 1997 budget assumptions. [CORRECTED 00:15 GMT 7/11]

text.p: Petroleos Mexicanos (Pemex) head Adrian Lajous told Mexican congressional deputies on Wednesday that the government's 1997 federal government budget assumes an average crude oil export price of $14.50 per barrel.

Such estimates would imply a $1.3 billion loss in revenue next year to about $9 billion from 1996 levels, the director general of the nation's oil and gas monopoly said in testimony to a congressional energy commission.

The forecast is a conservative one, Lajous said, considering crude oil prices are expected to remain about $18 per barrel through the end of 1996. (Corrects to delete erroneous interpretation of Lajous' remarks.)
"Greater volume could compensate for a possible fall in prices," Lajous said.

He estimated that total crude oil exports revenues would hit about $10 billion during 1996. Pemex expects crude output in 1997 to rise by 7.7 percent to 3.08 million bpd (Corrects to add expected crude output rise.)
